contents:
When you’re a kid, everything is astonishing. Everything is new. And so your brain is awake and turned on. So every second, your brain is learning something new: how the world works. And so the muscle of your brain is activated.
And as you get older and your brain has figured out the patterns of how the world works: this is how you make money; this is how you graduate school; this is how you get a mortgage; this is how you have kids… And once your brain establishes a routine, it stops.
The alertness and the fascination with how the world works go away. That’s what travel is in general - it wakes up your brain.
title: When You're a Kid

“Whatever you do, decide, and do it right away, which in itself makes people lively and maintains a sense of initiative and happiness.”
title: Shi's Understanding of Procrastination

“Political correctness” was quietly discussed at the time of the victory of “Everything Everywhere All at Once”. This view arose early when Moonlight Boy won the award that year; after all, it was another hard look at the rise of minorities.
Some people say that “political correctness” is the biggest source of antipathy for hypocrisy - a polite and friendly way to give way to smiling may follow the social identity of “good citizens,” as to the extent to which this act of kindness is due to “you” is hard to know.
But what is clear is that without the “political correctness” shield, discrimination and prejudice will only be more direct and severe. No one can retreat from the “motive” of torture.
“Judge me by my deeds not intentions”
title: Oscar
